text:
Hey Paulina! I hope you are doing okay and are keeping safe? It’s a pretty crazy world now hey? Hope you are feeling okay, feel free to vent to me about things that are bothering you if you want.. I’m going to be making sure to check this every day.
(I’ve been busy and caught up in all the coronavirus drama too and I still don’t seem to get notifications on here which is very annoying! So I’m just going to have this tab pinned to my browser from now on!)

I can’t imagine how difficult it must be to work on your short film remotely… but in some ways this is a great time to learn those essential skills for communication. I have a feeling that the virus is really going to change how the industry views remote work in the future. I hope that companies are going to be more understanding of people who wish to work remotely.

(When I was a freelancer I found it difficult to get remote work, mostly because companies can’t keep checking on you like they would if you were in the office.
I think one good thing to come out of this is that companies should learn that they _can_ trust their employees to do their jobs!)

Thank you for sharing your CV - your website is looking fantastic too, really nice and easy to navigate and you are showing off your work well. The only thing I’d say about your modelling showreel vid is that people really love to see wireframes, so I’d recommend adding that too.

Your CV is great, I really love how you have thought about how you can apply the skills you learnt throughout your education to a role in VFX. You’ve made me realise too, the skills you are learning through remote working in isolation right now can definitely go on your CV... I imagine companies will probably want to know what you did during a global crisis! :earth_africa:

Ah I am so excited about Fusspot, it’s looking incredible, really well done for your hard work so far!!! Fingers crossed for you that the renders can get sorted - can you push back a little on your deadline because of current circumstances or do you think you’ll still be able to get things done in time? :monkey:

I think I miss the fast pace of film. It’s not easy when you first start out as a junior artist, it can be so stressful, and there are differences in how each VFX company treats their staff...
I only ever had experience working in-house at Framestore (which was at times super stressful, but also a place where I made tons of friends, felt like I had made huge achievements and impressed very senior staff, and got that thrill of pulling off difficult work with seconds to go..) and at a small VFX studio which quite honestly was absolute hell, a boss who - to put it bluntly - was a bully, a team made up of mostly freelancers who all left the project early and at random times so the whole project would get harder and harder the closer it got to the deadline.. :exploding_head:

So it seems kind of nuts to want to leave my current position; games are way more chill, the team is generally very happy and friendly, we have fun social nights and the company takes amazing care of us. The project is a dream to work on, things are going smoothly even despite the whole company having to work remote now.
But I just really love London, so I think a big part of my desire to go back to Film is because I just like that lifestyle - it works for me right now at my age and point in life etc.
The role I have right now is one I could see myself settling into and doing for 5+ years. I’m just not ready to settle yet!

I look forward to hearing more from you anyway, no pressure to write to me if you are busy with stuff of course (and I have written a proper wall of text there haha, sorry about that!) Take care of yourself :blush:
